posts.title: Installing and Configuring Oracle Linux 9
posts.content:
Oracle Database 23ai, rebranded from Oracle 23c, is a new long-term support release from Oracle. It brings over 300 new features that include, but are not limited to, AI Vector Search, SQL Firewall, True Cache, and other schema enhancements. You can learn more here.

This tutorial takes you first through Installing Oracle Linux 9.4 on a VMware Workstation 17 Player instance. Then, Oracle 23ai database will be installed and configured. Lastly, an existing schema will be installed that will allow you to go through basic Oracle database statements. This guide assumes you have the minimal PC hardware requirements and working knowledge of the command-line interface.

Prerequisites

Minimal PC Hardware Requirements

  • RAM: 2 GB RAM - recommended

  • Hard Disk Space: At least 20GB of empty space. 40GB is recommended.

  • A minimum of 2 logical CPUs

  • Processor: Based on either Intel EM64T or AMD64 architecture

  • At least 1024 x 768 display resolution

  • VMware Workstation 17 Player or VirtualBox - This guide uses VMware Workstation 17 Player. Note that obtaining VMware is now done through Broadcom. Please follow their steps to download it. If it proves to be too much of a struggle, VirtualBox is definitely a good alternative.

  • An Oracle account

  • Working knowledge of the command-line interface (terminal)

Installation Steps

  • Install and Configure an Oracle Linux 9 VM instance.

  • System Preparation

  • Database 23ai Installation

  • Default Schema Installation

  • Basic commands

  • Uninstall steps

Step 1: Install and Configure Oracle Linux 9

First, you need to download the .iso file. Navigate to https://yum.oracle.com/oracle-linux-isos.html

Click the .iso file under Full ISO for the 9.4 Release.

The file will start downloading

Open VMware (or Virtualbox).

Click on ‘Create a New Virtual Machine’. You can also navigate to Player > File > New Virtual Machine.

Choose ‘Installer disk image file (iso)’. Select Browse and select the location where you downloaded the Oracle Linux iso. Click ‘Next’.

Enter a name for the virtual machine, then choose the drive path where you want the VM instance to reside. Click ‘Next’.

Change the maximum disk size to your preferred size and select ‘Store virtual disk as a single file’.

Click on ‘Customize Hardware’. You can leave ‘Power on this virtual machine after creation’ checked.

Under Memory, move the blue arrow to ‘4GB’, or your preferred memory amount.

Select Processors and choose the number of processor cores to dedicate to the VM. You can keep the default of 2 or change it as needed.

Click on ‘Network Adapters’ and choose Bridged under Network Connection. Also make sure that ‘Connected’ and ‘Connect at power On’ are checked under Device Status. Click OK when finished.

Navigate back to the VMware default screen. Click the newly created VM and select ‘Play virtual machine’.

Upon successful startup, you will be met with the installer screen. Use the up-arrow key to navigate to and choose ‘Install Oracle Linux 9.4.0.’

Select the appropriate language and click ‘Continue’.

Click on ‘Installation Destination’

Select the disk that Oracle 9 will be installed on. You may need to click on it twice. (In cases like this, where it is installed locally, it will be the location you chose in step 7). Click ‘Done’ when finished.

Select ‘Root Password’ under User Settings.

Uncheck ‘Lock root account’ and enter in a password to use for the root account.

Back under User Settings click on ‘User Creation’. The Create User window will appear. Enter in a Full name (does not have to be your name) and an User name. Ensure that ‘Make this user administrator’ is checked. Enter a password for the user. When you are finished, click ‘Done’.

Optional – Back at the default install screen Click on ‘Kdump’ and disable it.

Confirm your settings and click ‘Begin Installation’.

The installation will begin.

Upon successful installation, you will receive notification that it is complete. Click on ‘Reboot System’.

Upon successful reboot the login screen will appear. Login with your username and password.

Now that you have Oracle Linux 9 installed and configured, it’s time to set up the system for the installation and configuration of Oracle Database 19c (RPM).

Step 2: Configure the System

Before the database is installed, some configurations to the system need to be performed to ensure proper functionality when installing and interacting with the database.

To begin, make sure the system is up to date - enter the ‘sudo yum update’ command. Confirm what is being installed and click ‘y’ at the prompt(s).

Once the updates are complete, reboot the system using ‘sudo systemctl reboot’ and log back in.

Now, you need to configure the network.

Click on the network icon in the top right corner of the display. Click on ‘Wired Settings’.

Take note of the IPV4 address and DNS information.

Click on the IPV4 tab, then select the ‘Manual’ method. Fill in the Address, Netmask, Gateway and DNS information from the previous step.

Go back to the default Network window and toggle the Wired connection slider off and then on again. Ensure the wired connection is changed and established.

Enter the ‘hostnamectl set-hostname’ command to set a hostname; this will allow ease of identification and configuration over the network.

Now, you need to add the hostname to the /etc/hosts file. Open it with a text editor such as nano or vim.

Set the correct IP and hostname. Save the file when finished.

Open the /etc/selinux/config file.

Navigate to and change the line that reads SELINUX=enforcing to permissive. Save it when done.

Enter the ‘setenforce Permissive’ command and then use ‘getenforce’ to confirm the change.

The Linux firewall is usually enabled by default. This will need to be disabled to ensure proper installation and functionality of the database. Disable the Linux firewall by entering the ‘systemctl stop firewalld’ command, then ‘sudo systemctl disable firewalld’.

Enter the ‘systemctl status firewalld’ command to confirm it is disabled.

Now that the system and network have applicable configuration, you will run and install the Database Preinstallation.

Step 3: Install Oracle 23ai Database

Log in as root

Enter the command -’sudo dnf -y install oracle-database-preinstall-23ai’- to install the Oracle Database Preinstall RPM Package. This automatically downloads and installs any needed RPM packaged, settings, parameters, an oracle user and applicable groups for the user.

Change to the /tmp directory.

Download and Install the 23ai software using the following command – sudo yum install -y https://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/otn_software/db-free/oracle-database-free-23ai-1.0 -1.el9.x86_64.rpm’.

Once successfully downloaded and installed you will receive a message that it is ‘Complete!’

(Optional) Confirm the presence of and review the RPM log file.

Confirm the presence of the ORACLE_HOME path.

Step 4: Create and Configure the Oracle Database

Execute the configuration script as shown below. This creates a container database (FREEPDB1) with one pluggable database and configures the listener (default port 1521). These parameters can be modified by editing the oraclefree-23ai.conf file.

Create and confirm a password for the database.

You will receive a message that the installation is complete. The database and listener are automatically started after the configuration is complete.

(Optional) The configuration parameters can be modified by editing the oraclefree-23ai.conf file.

/etc/sysconfig/oracle-free-23ai.conf

Set a password for the oracle user.

Switch to the Oracle user account

Open the .bash_profile file

Edit the file with the code below to configure specific environment variables.

export ORACLE_SID=FREE

export ORACLE_HOME=/opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree

export ORAENV_ASK=NO

export PATH=$ORACLE_HOME/bin:$PATH

Reload the profile.

Confirm the presence of the $ORACLE_HOME path

Check and confirm the status of the listener

Step 5: Connect to the Database

Connect to the pluggable database with the SYS user. (sqlplus sys@localhost:1521/FREEPDB1 as sysdba)

Enter the password you created earlier for the database.

Use the ‘show pdbs command to view the PDB(s).

Use the ‘alter session set container = FREEPDB1’; statement to switch to the FREEPDB1 database.

If at any time you want to exit the database se the ‘exit’ command.

Step 5: Install a Sample Schema

In this section you will install the HR sample schema. This will allow you to explore Oracle database commands further.

Switch to the /tmp directory

The sample schema you will be installing is available at Github. Use ‘wget https://github.com/oracle-samples/db-sample-schemas/archive/refs/tags/v23.3.zip’ to download the file to the /tmp directory.

Confirm the presence of the file using the ‘echo’ command.

Move the file into the $ORACLE_HOME/demo/schema directory

Switch to the $ORACLE_HOME/demo/schema directory

Confirm the presence of the zip file using the ‘ls’ command.

Unzip the file

Go back to your database session. Log back in if needed.

Enter the ‘@/opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree/demo/schema/db-sample-schemas-23.3/human_resources/hr_install.sql’ command to install the HR database.

Enter a password for the HR user. Then, enter an appropriate table name for the user and type ‘yes’.

The installation will run, creating the default tables. Once complete you will be disconnected from the database.

Before you log in with the hr user, you need to edit the tnsnames.ora file. Navigate to /opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree/network/admin and open the tnsnames.ora file

Add the following lines to the file and save it.

FREEPDB1 =

(DESCRIPTION =

(ADDRESS = (PROTOCOL = TCP)(HOST = orc-23ai.localhost)(PORT = 1521))

(CONNECT_DATA =

(SERVER = DEDICATED)

(SERVICE_NAME = freepdb1)

)

)

Connect to the HR user. You should get the following response indicating a successful connection. You are now free to navigate the database, create a table or perform other SQL functions. A guide on entering executing using SQL*Plus statements can be found here.

Step 7: Remove Oracle 23ai

Exit out of the database session, if it’s still running.

Log in as root

Use the deinstall command found in the $ORACLE_HOME/deinstall directory. This process deletes Oracle Database configuration files, user data, and fast recovery area (FRA) files, even if they are stored outside the Oracle base directory path.

Or you can do a manual uninstall with the following:

Enter the ‘/etc/init.d/oracle-free-23ai delete’ command. This removes all the oracle database free files, the listener and configuration files.

Next, enter ‘yum remove oracle-database-free-23ai’. This removes the software.

(Optional) If you solely installed Oracle Database Free on your system without any additional Oracle Database software, you may also proceed to uninstall the Oracle Database Preinstallation RPM.

yum remove oracle-database-preinstall-23ai

Manually delete the downloaded RPM files

Rm oracle-database-preinstall-23ai*

Rm oracle-database-free-23ai*

For a more in depth tutorial on removing Oracle 23ai see this blog.

Conclusion

I hope the steps in this guide were useful for setting up Oracle Linux 23ai on Oracle Linux 9 in a VMware environment. I authored this last year in hopes that I would have the opportunity to get it posted on a site like Digital Ocean. However, and like a few others, they have halted their writer program for the time being. So, I finally decided to post it here. :)

Have any suggestions? Please leave useful, constructive feedback
posts.contentMarkdown:
Oracle Database 23ai, rebranded from Oracle 23c, is a new long-term support release from Oracle. It brings over 300 new features that include, but are not limited to, AI Vector Search, SQL Firewall, True Cache, and other schema enhancements. You can learn more [here.](https://www.oracle.com/database/faq/)

This tutorial takes you first through Installing Oracle Linux 9.4 on a VMware Workstation 17 Player instance. Then, Oracle 23ai database will be installed and configured. Lastly, an existing schema will be installed that will allow you to go through basic Oracle database statements. This guide assumes you have the minimal PC hardware requirements and working knowledge of the command-line interface.

### **Prerequisites**

**Minimal PC Hardware Requirements**

* RAM: 2 GB RAM - recommended
    
* Hard Disk Space: At least 20GB of empty space. 40GB is recommended.
    
* A minimum of 2 logical CPUs
    
* Processor: Based on either Intel EM64T or AMD64 architecture
    
* At least 1024 x 768 display resolution
    
* [VMware Workstation 17 Player](https://knowledge.broadcom.com/external/article/368734/download-desktop-hypervisor-workstation.html) or [VirtualBox](https://www.virtualbox.org/) - This guide uses VMware Workstation 17 Player. *Note that obtaining VMware is now done through Broadcom. Please follow their steps to download it. If it proves to be too much of a struggle, VirtualBox is definitely a good alternative.*
    
* [An Oracle account](https://signon.oracle.com/signin)
    
* Working knowledge of the command-line interface (terminal)
    

### Installation Steps

* Install and Configure an Oracle Linux 9 VM instance.
    
* System Preparation
    
* Database 23ai Installation
    
* Default Schema Installation
    
* Basic commands
    
* Uninstall steps
    

## Step 1: Install and Configure Oracle Linux 9

First, you need to download the .iso file. Navigate to [https://yum.oracle.com/oracle-linux-isos.html](https://yum.oracle.com/oracle-linux-isos.html)

Click the .iso file under Full ISO for the 9.4 Release.

The file will start downloading

Open VMware (or Virtualbox).

Click on ‘Create a New Virtual Machine’. You can also navigate to Player > File > New Virtual Machine.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941485589/b3f6c0ea-f5be-486f-a608-13d1bdf3f6b5.png align="left")

Choose ‘Installer disk image file (iso)’. Select Browse and select the location where you downloaded the Oracle Linux iso. Click ‘Next’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941506680/7cbe9fd2-c070-461f-9f50-e5e072db15b4.png align="left")

Enter a name for the virtual machine, then choose the drive path where you want the VM instance to reside. Click ‘Next’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941558387/4e2843a0-331c-424b-8ace-25a49552b20b.png align="left")

Change the maximum disk size to your preferred size and select ‘Store virtual disk as a single file’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941732361/3a529e15-4b53-473b-9ec7-4d430e76ffed.png align="left")

Click on ‘Customize Hardware’. You can leave ‘Power on this virtual machine after creation’ checked.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941747124/0e32d7a0-46f0-4234-927f-55b7acdbf6b7.png align="left")

Under Memory, move the blue arrow to ‘4GB’, or your preferred memory amount.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941760659/28afb755-8f03-4a02-b944-a4edadcc083d.png align="left")

Select Processors and choose the number of processor cores to dedicate to the VM. You can keep the default of 2 or change it as needed.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941773895/8ce24908-26b8-47ed-8bbf-5b9ce25d93b4.png align="left")

Click on ‘Network Adapters’ and choose Bridged under Network Connection. Also make sure that ‘Connected’ and ‘Connect at power On’ are checked under Device Status. Click OK when finished.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941789209/1734ac7b-08c7-4fcc-a64c-e93633c21aa5.png align="left")

Navigate back to the VMware default screen. Click the newly created VM and select ‘Play virtual machine’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941870000/6920f42f-92ba-4103-a10f-92192e890030.png align="left")

Upon successful startup, you will be met with the installer screen. Use the up-arrow key to navigate to and choose ‘Install Oracle Linux 9.4.0.’

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941882569/cf596b94-4f8a-48ee-82ad-df9a21c9d9b2.png align="left")

Select the appropriate language and click ‘Continue’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941894805/90d183c1-4faf-446f-bfff-b22a945640fc.png align="left")

Click on ‘Installation Destination’

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941909752/37c0665a-79a4-4412-abac-b868a7704d86.png align="left")

Select the disk that Oracle 9 will be installed on. You may need to click on it twice. (In cases like this, where it is installed locally, it will be the location you chose in step 7). Click ‘Done’ when finished.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941943724/3c5357a7-a11f-49d8-9685-7a678fb21885.png align="left")

Select ‘Root Password’ under User Settings.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941957078/1b36bc24-ff67-4451-a12c-5aa4d95a0282.png align="left")

Uncheck ‘Lock root account’ and enter in a password to use for the root account.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941969844/1a19d1b5-2c82-47ec-9fb8-51262c65aa65.png align="left")

Back under User Settings click on ‘User Creation’. The Create User window will appear. Enter in a Full name (does not have to be your name) and an User name. Ensure that ‘Make this user administrator’ is checked. Enter a password for the user. When you are finished, click ‘Done’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941981931/239f1cb1-21c3-43dc-a259-1d798e93cf98.png align="left")

*Optional* – Back at the default install screen Click on ‘Kdump’ and disable it.

Confirm your settings and click ‘Begin Installation’.

The installation will begin.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741941996088/f59dafd0-daca-40d1-b6a8-f44730b0593f.png align="left")

Upon successful installation, you will receive notification that it is complete. Click on ‘Reboot System’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942007754/a182e752-7508-4e63-a12d-25cc4446007d.png align="left")

Upon successful reboot the login screen will appear. Login with your username and password.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942024919/31413766-9cba-47c8-901b-8d0b8e117a6c.png align="left")

*Now that you have Oracle Linux 9 installed and configured, it’s time to set up the system for the installation and configuration of Oracle Database 19c (RPM).*

## Step 2: Configure the System

Before the database is installed, some configurations to the system need to be performed to ensure proper functionality when installing and interacting with the database.

To begin, make sure the system is up to date - enter the ‘*sudo yum update*’ command. Confirm what is being installed and click ‘y’ at the prompt(s).

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942065107/7eff50f4-71d6-4a50-b517-dd014c65bd89.png align="left")

Once the updates are complete, reboot the system using *‘sudo systemctl reboot’* and log back in.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942077142/2ae77dc6-a891-4fa6-8a7c-fec4a2038214.png align="left")

Now, you need to configure the network.

Click on the network icon in the top right corner of the display. Click on ‘Wired Settings’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942155409/dac00cad-73fa-4657-951a-447c5f4d717c.png align="left")

Take note of the IPV4 address and DNS information.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942246349/11fff7bb-04f6-451b-b435-ff1cd67ef417.png align="left")

Click on the IPV4 tab, then select the ‘Manual’ method. Fill in the Address, Netmask, Gateway and DNS information from the previous step.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942256926/6e6e3279-9cad-4a7a-aa80-b13c01a98bf2.png align="left")

Go back to the default Network window and toggle the Wired connection slider off and then on again. Ensure the wired connection is changed and established.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942271302/eb11f2e5-b0db-40e5-ab72-0feef218cb57.png align="left")

Enter the ‘*hostnamectl set-hostname’* command to set a hostname; this will allow ease of identification and configuration over the network.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942284329/a192dbd3-5ff6-4691-bede-e8dff5a35169.png align="left")

Now, you need to add the hostname to the /etc/hosts file. Open it with a text editor such as nano or vim.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942296362/a1199a1b-fb82-4138-a38e-954968d11546.png align="left")

Set the correct IP and hostname. Save the file when finished.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942308705/7183ff84-caaf-4146-a1af-60fb6385b4ae.png align="left")

Open the /etc/selinux/config file.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942324262/adc24440-8178-44a6-baad-a223e34a069f.png align="left")

Navigate to and change the line that reads SELINUX=enforcing to permissive. Save it when done.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942336192/a9c5ba29-4b55-45fb-ab43-88a21b60c806.png align="left")

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942342048/49709ed0-9dcd-44cb-9368-4183eddd6a39.png align="left")

Enter the ‘*setenforce Permissive’* command and then use ‘*getenforce*’ to confirm the change.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942357458/14922301-97cd-43b3-bc90-e0ab9f360ac9.png align="left")

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942363068/d0489eed-ddcb-4e8e-b496-7823292a4c06.png align="left")

The Linux firewall is usually enabled by default. This will need to be disabled to ensure proper installation and functionality of the database. Disable the Linux firewall by entering the ‘*systemctl stop firewalld’* command, then ‘*sudo systemctl disable firewalld’*.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942391627/f05caf84-0835-4ac8-a8ae-c8fd517294f3.png align="left")

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942399596/1f4618e1-bcda-4425-8de0-926dc8576af9.png align="left")

Enter the ‘*systemctl status firewalld’* command to confirm it is disabled.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942415365/e0733fc4-68ed-44ae-b0ce-0e7953c87738.png align="left")

*Now that the system and network have applicable configuration, you will run and install the Database Preinstallation.*

## Step 3: Install Oracle 23ai Database

Log in as root

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942507256/ba3ef1d0-0d7b-406f-bb06-441a393f0609.png align="left")

Enter the command -*’sudo dnf -y install oracle-database-preinstall-23ai’*\- to install the Oracle Database Preinstall RPM Package. This automatically downloads and installs any needed RPM packaged, settings, parameters, an oracle user and applicable groups for the user.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942705638/7349aa8a-49f4-4143-a9ee-f6f5a9b1b97b.png align="left")

Change to the /tmp directory.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942764546/a114d447-3a0b-4796-a061-f975c7ff44da.png align="left")

Download and Install the 23ai software using the following command – *sudo yum install -y*  [*https://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/otn\_software/db-free/oracle-database-free-23ai-1.0*](https://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/otn_software/db-free/oracle-database-free-23ai-1.0) *\-1.el9.x86\_64.rpm’*.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942779218/d301703b-f7f0-4d2b-a726-694bf9c7937b.png align="left")

Once successfully downloaded and installed you will receive a message that it is ‘Complete!’

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942796783/4343e059-e47d-4fa5-a959-6006c62a1cbf.png align="left")

(Optional) Confirm the presence of and review the RPM log file.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942823875/43811ec2-caaf-4470-b6ce-fd88e92bd58d.png align="left")

Confirm the presence of the ORACLE\_HOME path.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942836575/f2d935e8-1a6e-4220-9865-6d9ba93cae78.png align="left")

## Step 4: Create and Configure the Oracle Database

Execute the configuration script as shown below. This creates a container database (FREEPDB1) with one pluggable database and configures the listener (default port 1521). These parameters can be modified by editing the oraclefree-23ai.conf file.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942873739/64cce1b4-42d0-4921-8abe-0ec044b36026.png align="left")

Create and confirm a password for the database.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942885956/6b577a7b-93d4-4057-b54c-6439a0882958.png align="left")

You will receive a message that the installation is complete. The database and listener are automatically started after the configuration is complete.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942954620/48093fb2-ad82-45bf-a3e4-3ebda4325e96.png align="left")

*(Optional)* The configuration parameters can be modified by editing the oraclefree-23ai.conf file.

**/etc/sysconfig/oracle-free-23ai.conf**

Set a password for the oracle user.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942969102/b3ea275d-2c42-4a37-b40e-3b67c8b794d6.png align="left")

Switch to the Oracle user account

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942981874/a54fe0e3-ae7d-4d97-9a0b-520e9693b745.png align="left")

Open the .bash\_profile file

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741942991370/1155879f-16ea-4b17-8d8e-7a9e4351c392.png align="left")

Edit the file with the code below to configure specific environment variables.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943002398/7532badb-af3f-4858-88b9-2f591bdc353c.png align="left")

*export ORACLE\_SID=FREE*

*export ORACLE\_HOME=/opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree*

*export ORAENV\_ASK=NO*

*export PATH=$ORACLE\_HOME/bin:$PATH*

Reload the profile.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943043984/692e3325-03f0-4d12-b9a9-f49535cc33fe.png align="left")

Confirm the presence of the $ORACLE\_HOME path

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943056099/9794c901-d3c2-4fed-bada-cd4e0c6f592f.png align="left")

Check and confirm the status of the listener

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943074073/113a43bb-8d33-4e1c-9bda-34c3d7ccec63.png align="left")

## Step 5: Connect to the Database

Connect to the pluggable database with the SYS user. (sqlplus sys@localhost:1521/FREEPDB1 as sysdba)

Enter the password you created earlier for the database.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943143351/ee1e0444-ed8f-4236-a23b-173a2527eb6c.png align="left")

Use the ‘show pdbs command to view the PDB(s).

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943154959/feb3ac04-7313-470d-a855-d9d15bc8e3ec.png align="left")

Use the *‘alter session set container = FREEPDB1’;* statement to switch to the FREEPDB1 database.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943169506/c67bda28-38d6-4a2c-9c4a-dc24760a4e0a.png align="left")

If at any time you want to exit the database se the ‘exit’ command.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943180377/827d23d2-9afb-46da-a75c-19ad7133f7d8.png align="left")

## Step 5: Install a Sample Schema

In this section you will install the HR sample schema. This will allow you to explore Oracle database commands further.

Switch to the /tmp directory

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943267922/45c43d7e-0762-4a05-be21-5057a7aa8d9f.png align="left")

The sample schema you will be installing is available at [Github](https://github.com/oracle-samples/db-sample-schemas/releases/tag/v23.3). Use *‘wget* [*https://github.com/oracle-samples/db-sample-schemas/archive/refs/tags/v23.3.zip*](https://github.com/oracle-samples/db-sample-schemas/archive/refs/tags/v23.3.zip)*’* to download the file to the /tmp directory.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943326013/0d7584d5-12d6-40fc-9562-0053198b33cc.png align="left")

Confirm the presence of the file using the ‘echo’ command.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943338299/c17c0cd1-51c7-477a-870f-2355ac93c406.png align="left")

Move the file into the $ORACLE\_HOME/demo/schema directory

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943349366/53d00516-49f5-4568-b8b2-831b7399868d.png align="left")

Switch to the $ORACLE\_HOME/demo/schema directory

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943360711/93502d9b-80a9-4d04-92fd-6128ed7068e3.png align="left")

Confirm the presence of the zip file using the ‘ls’ command.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943373322/506c365e-9ab0-49c4-802c-f7ff6b272388.png align="left")

Unzip the file

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943390104/1f284830-9146-44b1-a4a3-ec13aed6b712.png align="left")

Go back to your database session. Log back in if needed.

Enter the *‘@/opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree/demo/schema/db-sample-schemas-23.3/human\_resources/hr\_install.sql’* command to install the HR database.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943410457/e3d7672a-b346-4d25-8876-ab3ec2928461.png align="left")

Enter a password for the HR user. Then, enter an appropriate table name for the user and type ‘yes’.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943423257/bfcce93c-9419-42ee-a048-9d85c3ac0e9d.png align="left")

The installation will run, creating the default tables. Once complete you will be disconnected from the database.

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943435127/3865000b-3076-474e-90f0-313d7adab1a6.png align="left")

Before you log in with the hr user, you need to edit the tnsnames.ora file. Navigate to /opt/oracle/product/23ai/dbhomeFree/network/admin and open the tnsnames.ora file

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943447236/dea60eaa-b64c-44c5-9774-4ca272ad229f.png align="left")

Add the following lines to the file and save it.

FREEPDB1 =

(DESCRIPTION =

(ADDRESS = (PROTOCOL = TCP)(HOST = orc-23ai.[localhost](http://localhost))(PORT = 1521))

(CONNECT\_DATA =

(SERVER = DEDICATED)

(SERVICE\_NAME = freepdb1)

)

)

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943464575/13b4f139-a05d-462b-bf8b-ff40ca9d37eb.png align="left")

Connect to the HR user. You should get the following response indicating a successful connection. You are now free to navigate the database, create a table or perform other SQL functions. A guide on entering executing using SQL\*Plus statements can be found [here](https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/23/sqpug/SQL-Plus-quick-start.html#GUID-51621F21-7C1D-4A75-8B00-20F9460FC339).

![](https://cdn.hashnode.com/res/hashnode/image/upload/v1741943480715/63ee6bbc-7688-46e9-b21e-1bf3452c92ac.png align="left")

## Step 7: Remove Oracle 23ai

Exit out of the database session, if it’s still running.

Log in as root

Use the deinstall command found in the $ORACLE\_HOME/deinstall directory. This process deletes Oracle Database configuration files, user data, and fast recovery area (FRA) files, even if they are stored outside the Oracle base directory path.

Or you can do a manual uninstall with the following:

Enter the ‘*/etc/init.d/oracle-free-23ai delete’* command. This removes all the oracle database free files, the listener and configuration files.

Next, enter ‘*yum remove oracle-database-free-23ai’*. This removes the software.

(Optional) If you solely installed Oracle Database Free on your system without any additional Oracle Database software, you may also proceed to uninstall the Oracle Database Preinstallation RPM.

*yum remove oracle-database-preinstall-23ai*

Manually delete the downloaded RPM files

*Rm oracle-database-preinstall-23ai\**

*Rm oracle-database-free-23ai\**

For a more in depth tutorial on removing Oracle 23ai see this [blog](https://rupeshanantghubade.blogspot.com/2024/05/deinstalling-oracle-database-23ai.html).

## Conclusion

I hope the steps in this guide were useful for setting up Oracle Linux 23ai on Oracle Linux 9 in a VMware environment. I authored this last year in hopes that I would have the opportunity to get it posted on a site like Digital Ocean. However, and like a few others, they have halted their writer program for the time being. So, I finally decided to post it here. :)

Have any suggestions? Please leave useful, constructive feedback

posts.author: 67d3e69d9dd99afb336524a0
posts.metaDescription: Learn how to install and configure Oracle Linux 9 and Oracle Database 23ai within a VMware environment with this comprehensive step-by-step guide.
